projects.title: Teaserfly
projects.summary: Automation suite for generating AI-driven teaser visuals and video packages across BILD platforms, integrating editorial workflows and design automation.
projects.impact: Reduced teaser production time by 90%, enabling editors to generate cross-platform media packages autonomously.
projects.story:
# The Challenge

The BILD editorial and design teams faced an increasing need for **fast, high-quality teaser creation** across multiple platforms, from Bild.de and Bild Play to YouTube, Instagram, and other social channels. The traditional process relied heavily on designers, taking up to 15 minutes per teaser, often under tight news deadlines.

# The Solution

To address this, we conceptualized and developed **Teaserfly**, a modular and scalable internal tool that automates teaser production using **AI generation, smart text suggestions, and media optimization**. The project was designed to fit seamlessly into existing publishing CMS, streamlining editorial and visual workflows.

### My Role

I played a key role in shaping the **concept, infraestructure, and AI research** behind Teaserfly. I also contributed to the **frontend architecture (React, TypeScript)** and **AI enhancement layer**.

# The Approach

Teaserfly was developed in multiple phases:

- **POC:** Manual MVP via Figma plugin for the Bundesliga vertical teaser.
- **Alpha:** Web prototype integrating text and image AI features.
- **Beta:** Expanded for all templates, auto-suggestions using article text.

![User Flow Diagram](/assets/projects/teaserfly/teaserFlyUserFlow.png)

# AI Features

- **Design Automation:** Smart cropping and layout adjustments using Amazon Rekognition.
- **Headline Optimization:** AI-powered text suggestions for each platform.
- **Add-on Intelligence:** Automatic inclusion of Ad elements, video tags, and logos.
- **Image Recommendations:** Sugestion of images based on the context.
- **Creation Agent – 'Teasy':** An optional assistant that helps editors refine graphics interactively.

# Integration

Teaserfly connects directly with internal publishing tools, ensuring editors can **create, preview, and publish teasers** in one flow:
- Pushes to **CMS** and **DAM System**.
- Supports export for third-party platforms (YouTube, Instagram).

<video controls style="width: 100%; border-radius: 1rem; margin: 2rem 0;">
  <source src="/assets/projects/teaserfly/teaserflyDemo.mp4" type="video/mp4">
  Your browser does not support the video tag.
</video>

# Results

- **90% reduction** in manual work time (from 15 min to 90 sec per teaser)
- **Standardized design output** across all formats
- **AI-powered scalability**, handling hundreds of assets daily
- **Empowered newsroom teams** to operate independently of design bottlenecks

# Future Vision

Teaserfly continues to evolve with the introduction of **personalization, A/B testing, and dynamic design adaptation** — using real-time performance data and multilingual optimization to push editorial automation even further.

This is a company project developed internally at Axel Springer GmbH, no public demo or code repository can be shared.

projects.title: Quem Fica em Pé
projects.summary: Game show control system for the Brazilian adaptation of 'Who’s Still Standing?', automating real-time graphics, questions, and prize management for live television broadcast.
projects.impact: Delivered a fully integrated real-time game control suite in two weeks, ensuring flawless live operation and boosting the show's premiere audience ratings on Band.
projects.story:
# The Challenge

In 2012, Rede Bandeirantes brought the international format of *'Who’s Still Standing?'* to Brazil, launching the game show **'Quem Fica em Pé'**, hosted by **José Luiz Datena**. The production demanded a complete digital control ecosystem built from scratch in just **two weeks** — responsible for managing every part of the game’s mechanics in real time.

![Studio Demo](/assets/projects/quemficaempe/demo.jpg)

The system needed to integrate seamlessly with **Vizrt broadcast graphics**, synchronize with the presenter’s timing, and guarantee the accurate calculation of prizes — totaling **over R$500,000** in awards across two seasons. According to the show’s Wikipedia page, the premiere significantly **improved Band’s audience ratings** in the São Paulo region.

# The Solution

A fully custom-built, C#-based platform was developed to manage the entire show logic, with three interconnected applications working in real time:

1. **Game Management System** – Proprietary CMS for registering over **3,000 questions**, managing rounds, prizes, and the complete rundown of each episode.
2. **Vizrt Control Connector** – Real-time TCP socket controller for graphics and animations displayed on the studio’s large screen, ensuring frame-perfect sync with Datena’s narration.
3. **Teleprompter System (TP)** – Interface for presenters and contestants displaying dynamic instructions and timed content during live recording.

 ![SystemScreen](/assets/projects/quemficaempe/tela1.png)

# My Role

I designed the system’s architecture, coded every module, and developed **custom connectors for Vizrt integration**. My responsibilities included:

- Building the CMS and control interfaces
- Implementing the scoring and prize logic
- Managing TCP socket communication between systems
- Supporting live studio operations throughout the first season

# The Approach

Development was fast-paced and highly collaborative. I worked closely with the **engineering, art, and direction teams** to align visual and technical workflows. The system’s architecture combined **C#**, **PostgreSQL**, and **TCP-based real-time control**, delivering a stable, low-latency experience during broadcast.

# Team & Production

- **Program Director:** Pablo Mazover  
- **Production Coordination:** Eduardo Gaspar  
- **Art Direction:** Omar Sabbag  
- **Art Coordination:** Pedro Coelho  
- **Engineering Coordination:** Thiago Perrela / Carol Garcia  

# Results

- **Full delivery within two weeks** before the live premiere
- **Zero technical failures** during broadcast
- **Perfect synchronization** between presenter, visuals, and scoring system
- **Boosted Band’s audience ratings** in the premiere week
- Early Brazilian example of **live game automation integrated with broadcast graphics**

<video controls style="width: 100%; border-radius: 1rem; margin: 2rem 0;">
  <source src="/assets/projects/quemficaempe/demo.mp4" type="video/mp4">
  Your browser does not support the video tag.
</video>

# Legacy

'Quem Fica em Pé' set a benchmark for **interactive broadcast automation** in Brazilian television, inspiring future projects focused on real-time synchronization and audience engagement.

projects.title: Riot Games – CBLOL Telemetry 2016
projects.summary: Real-time telemetry system integrating biometric data from players into live eSports broadcasts for Riot Games' CBLOL 2016, connecting Zephyr sensors to Vizrt graphics via custom-built C# software.
projects.impact: Delivered the first human telemetry integration in Brazilian eSports broadcasts, enriching live storytelling under high operational pressure and compliance constraints.
projects.story:
# The Challenge

During the **CBLOL 2016** broadcasts, **Riot Games Brasil** aimed to redefine the eSports viewing experience by introducing **human telemetry**—tracking players’ heart rate, breathing, and stress levels—to reveal the physical and emotional intensity behind professional gaming.

The initiative took place under **significant pressure from Riot’s production leadership**, as audience numbers were at record highs and expectations for innovation were enormous. Furthermore, strict **compliance and operational safety policies** mandated that no system could interfere with gameplay performance or jeopardize the broadcast, even in case of failure.

The technical environment posed additional challenges: over **2,000 spectators** in the arena, high electromagnetic interference, and numerous wireless devices caused instability in Bluetooth communications.

# The Solution

Working as a **freelance systems engineer**, I developed a two-part telemetry pipeline connecting **Zephyr biometric sensors** worn by the ten players to the **Vizrt** graphics system operated by **wTVision**. The goal was to stream real-time physiological data safely into the broadcast layer without impacting the competition.

Two complementary applications were built in **C#**:

1. **Bluetooth Reader (NUC – Under Stage)**  
   Installed beneath the main stage, this application handled **Bluetooth pairing, decoding, and data normalization** for all ten players’ Zephyr sensors. It managed signal stability and transmitted readings over **TCP Stream**.

2. **Telemetry Controller (Control Room)**  
   Running from the control room, it received data via TCP, processed and formatted it in **JSON**, and sent it via **UDP** to **Vizrt**, where graphics were updated live on screen. It also functioned as a monitoring dashboard, allowing real-time tracking of player vitals.

![System Diagram](/assets/projects/riot-telemetry/diagram.jpg)

# My Role

I was responsible for designing and coding both systems end-to-end:

- Built the **Bluetooth decoding layer** for Zephyr sensors.
- Implemented **TCP/UDP communication middleware** to link stage and control room with minimal latency.
- Developed a **real-time compliance logic** ensuring that signal loss would never impact gameplay or broadcast continuity.
- Supported **live operations** throughout the event, troubleshooting Bluetooth instability under high interference.

<video controls style="width: 100%; border-radius: 1rem; margin: 2rem 0;">
  <source src="/assets/projects/riot-telemetry/demo.mp4" type="video/mp4">
  Your browser does not support the video tag.
</video>

# The Approach

The project was executed in **three weeks**, involving close coordination between **Riot Games**, **wTVision**, and the local production crew. The architecture prioritized **redundancy, reliability, and isolation**, ensuring that any sensor or network failure would not affect live performance.

Although magnetic noise caused **some instability during the event**, the system remained operational and successfully displayed live biometric data throughout the competition—marking a pioneering moment in Brazilian eSports broadcasting.

# Results

- **First-ever human telemetry integration** in a Brazilian eSports broadcast.
- **Operational compliance** achieved — no interference with gameplay or broadcast continuity.
- **Functional real-time data visualization** via Vizrt graphics.
- **Performance rated as satisfactory** despite expected signal interference.
- Praised by **Riot Games Brasil** and **wTVision** as an innovative step forward for live eSports production.

![Control Room Screen](/assets/projects/riot-telemetry/screen1.png)

projects.title: BlueMarble
projects.summary: GFS weather tile generator that transforms NOAA meteorological data into interactive web map tiles, featuring 20+ meteorological variables, animated wind effects, and real-time visualization capabilities.
projects.impact: Deep dive into geospatial data processing, mastering GDAL workflows, understanding Web Mercator projections, and building complete data-to-visualization pipelines for meteorological applications.
projects.story:
# The Challenge

Understanding how modern weather mapping services like Windy, Ventusky, or Weather Underground work requires deep knowledge of geospatial data processing, meteorological formats, and web mapping technologies. The challenge was to build a complete pipeline that could:

- **Ingest raw NOAA GFS data** in GRIB2 format (a complex binary meteorological standard)
- **Process 20+ meteorological variables** including temperature, wind, precipitation, clouds, pressure, and specialized metrics like CAPE
- **Transform gridded data into web-ready map tiles** compatible with standard mapping libraries
- **Create visually compelling visualizations** with custom colormaps and transparency handling
- **Optimize performance** for processing large datasets (multi-gigabyte files)

![Weather Map Visualization](/assets/projects/blue-marble/demo.png)

# The Solution

BlueMarble is a comprehensive weather tile generation system that automates the entire pipeline from data download to interactive web visualization. The project demonstrates mastery of geospatial data processing while creating a practical tool for weather visualization.

### Technical Architecture

**Data Pipeline:**
1. **NOAA GFS Data Ingestion** – Automated download of forecast data
2. **GRIB2 Decoding** – Using cfgrib and xarray for data extraction
3. **Variable Processing** – Computing derived metrics (wind speed, apparent temperature)
4. **Geospatial Transformation** – Upsampling and Web Mercator reprojection via GDAL
5. **Tile Generation** – Parallel processing into PNG tiles with custom colormaps
6. **Storage & Delivery** – S3/MinIO deployment for web access

**Advanced Features:**
- **Custom Colormaps:** Specialized color schemes for different weather phenomena
- **Smart Transparency:** Alpha channels for low-value data (clouds <25%, precipitation <0.25mm)
- **Wind Animation:** Particle effects using leaflet-velocity for wind visualization
- **Multi-Layer Support:** Simultaneous overlay of multiple meteorological variables
- **Time Controls:** Interactive playback of forecast sequences

# The Approach

The project was developed as a **personal learning initiative** to understand the complete stack of modern weather visualization:

### Phase 1: Data Understanding
- Studied GRIB2 format specifications
- Analyzed NOAA GFS grid structure and coverage
- Researched meteorological variable standards and units

### Phase 2: Core Pipeline
- Implemented GDAL-based processing workflows
- Developed custom colormaps for each variable type
- Built reprojection and upsampling logic
- Created parallel tile generation system

### Phase 3: Web Integration
- Integrated Leaflet for interactive maps
- Implemented leaflet-velocity for wind animations
- Created responsive controls for layer and time management
- Optimized tile delivery and caching

### Phase 4: Deployment
- Dockerized the entire pipeline
- Implemented S3/MinIO storage integration
- Added memory management and resource limits
- Created comprehensive documentation

<video controls style="width: 100%; border-radius: 1rem; margin: 2rem 0;">
  <source src="/assets/projects/blue-marble/demo.mp4" type="video/mp4">
  Your browser does not support the video tag.
</video>

# Technology Deep Dive

### Geospatial Processing
- **GDAL (Geospatial Data Abstraction Library):** Industry-standard for raster operations
- **Web Mercator Projection:** EPSG:3857 for web mapping compatibility
- **Tile Pyramid:** Standard zoom levels (0-12) for progressive detail

### Meteorological Data
- **GRIB2 Format:** WMO standard for gridded meteorological data
- **Variable Coverage:** Temperature, humidity, wind (U/V components), precipitation, clouds, pressure, CAPE, and more
- **Temporal Resolution:** 1-hour forecast intervals

### Visualization
- **Matplotlib Colormaps:** Custom and standard schemes (viridis, plasma, jet)
- **Alpha Compositing:** Transparency for data emphasis and layering
- **Canvas Rendering:** HTML5 for smooth particle animations

# Results & Learning Outcomes

**Technical Mastery:**
- Comprehensive understanding of GDAL and geospatial transformations
- Proficiency with xarray and n-dimensional data manipulation
- Knowledge of Web Mercator projection and tile pyramid systems
- Experience with GRIB2 format and meteorological data standards

**System Design:**
- Built scalable data processing pipelines
- Implemented efficient parallel processing
- Designed modular architecture for easy extension
- Created deployment-ready containerized solution

**Web Development:**
- Integrated complex data visualization with Leaflet
- Implemented real-time animation systems
- Optimized asset delivery and caching strategies

**Practical Application:**
- Generated thousands of map tiles from multi-gigabyte datasets
- Created smooth 60fps wind animations
- Achieved memory-efficient processing within Docker constraints
- Built reusable pipeline applicable to other geospatial data sources

# Future Enhancements

Potential extensions include:
- **Additional Data Sources:** ERA5 reanalysis, satellite imagery, radar data
- **Mobile App:** Native iOS/Android weather visualization
- **API Layer:** RESTful service for programmatic access
- **Machine Learning:** Forecast correction and nowcasting models
- **3D Visualization:** WebGL-based atmospheric cross-sections

This project demonstrates the intersection of data engineering, geospatial processing, and web visualization — skills directly applicable to modern mapping platforms, environmental monitoring systems, and data-driven applications.

projects.title: Vizrt Birds
projects.summary: Interactive Angry Birds-style game built entirely in Vizrt's VBA scripting language, applying projectile motion physics and collision detection for touchscreen broadcast graphics. Community-shared tool demonstrating advanced scripting capabilities in VizArtist.
projects.impact: Successfully translated complex physics formulas from Python OOP training into Vizrt's native scripting environment, creating an accessible learning tool for the broadcast graphics community without requiring any plugins.
projects.story:
# The Challenge

In 2015, after completing a Python OOP training course focused on game development and physics simulation, I faced an interesting challenge: **could the projectile motion formulas and collision detection logic I learned in Python be implemented inside Vizrt's broadcast graphics environment?**

The technical hurdles were significant:

- **Language Translation**: Converting Python code to VBA (Vizrt's scripting language)
- **Physics Implementation**: Implementing trajectory calculations without external libraries
- **Interactive Controls**: Creating touchscreen-based gameplay mechanics
- **Performance**: Ensuring smooth real-time animation within Vizrt's rendering pipeline
- **No Plugins**: Building everything using only native VizArtist capabilities for maximum accessibility

![Vizrt Birds Screenshot](/assets/projects/vizbirds/banner.jpg)

# The Solution

**Vizrt Birds** is a fully functional Angry Birds-style game phase built entirely within VizArtist 3.6.3, demonstrating how broadcast graphics software can handle game physics and interactive logic typically reserved for game engines.

### Core Features

**Physics Simulation:**
- **Projectile Motion**: Implemented oblique launch calculations with constant gravity
  - Horizontal position: `X = X₀ + v·cos(θ)·Δt`
  - Vertical position: `Y = Y₀ + v·sin(θ)·Δt - (G·Δt²)/2`
- **Collision Detection**: Cartesian coordinate-based proximity detection
- **Trajectory Rendering**: Real-time path visualization

**Interactive Gameplay:**
- Touchscreen controls for aiming and launching
- Obstacle destruction mechanics
- Game state management

**Technical Architecture:**
- Pure VBA implementation (no plugins)
- Event-driven scripting for user interactions
- Frame-based animation system
- Modular code structure for extensibility

# The Approach

### Phase 1: Python Training Foundation

I completed the Python Birds training course (now available on [GitHub](https://github.com/ficosta/pythonbirds)), which taught:
- Object-oriented programming principles
- Projectile motion physics and mathematics
- Collision detection algorithms
- Game state management

### Phase 2: Physics Translation

The core challenge was translating Python's mathematical operations into VBA:

```python
# Python (from training)
X = X0 + velocity * cos(angle_radians) * delta_time
Y = Y0 + velocity * sin(angle_radians) * delta_time - (GRAVITY * delta_time²) / 2
```

This required:
- Converting trigonometric functions to VBA syntax
- Implementing radian-degree conversions
- Creating custom physics update loops
- Optimizing calculations for real-time performance

### Phase 3: Vizrt Implementation

Built the complete game logic within VizArtist:
- Created actor classes (birds, obstacles, targets)
- Implemented state machines (ACTIVE, LAUNCHED, DESTROYED)
- Developed touchscreen interaction handlers
- Added visual feedback and animation systems

### Phase 4: Community Release

Published on the Vizrt Forum (April 9, 2015) with:
- Complete VIA scene file for download
- No external dependencies or plugins
- Documentation for learning and customization

  <source src="/assets/projects/vizbirds/demo.mp4" type="video/mp4">
  Your browser does not support the video tag.
</video>

# Results & Community Impact

**Technical Achievement:**
- Successfully demonstrated game physics in broadcast graphics software
- Proved VBA's capability for complex mathematical simulations
- Created accessible learning resource (no plugins required)

**Community Reception:**
- Positive feedback from Vizrt community
- Downloaded and studied by fellow broadcast graphics professionals
- Inspired exploration of interactive graphics in news and sports broadcasts

**Personal Learning:**
- Deep understanding of physics simulation and numerical methods
- Mastery of VBA scripting within Vizrt ecosystem
- Experience bridging game development concepts with broadcast technology

# Download & Resources

**Try It Yourself:**
- [Download VIZRTBIRDS.via](/assets/projects/vizbirds/vizbirds.via) (1.0 MB)
- Compatible with VizArtist 3.6.3+
- No plugins required

**Source Code Reference:**
- [Python Birds Training Repo](https://github.com/ficosta/pythonbirds) - Original Python implementation
- [Vizrt Forum Thread](https://forum.vizrt.com/index.php?threads/viz-birds.15413/) - Community discussion

# Future Enhancements

Potential improvements mentioned in the original forum post:
- Object-oriented refactoring for better code organization
- Additional bird types with unique physics behaviors
- Enhanced particle effects for destruction animations
- Multiplayer/competitive modes for live broadcast engagement

This project represents the creative intersection of game development, physics simulation, and broadcast graphics — demonstrating that innovation often comes from applying concepts across unexpected domains.
